title: Drinks
text:
Barley Tea
Barley tea is a mild, caffeine-free drink that is enjoyed both hot and cold and is suitable for any time of day. It is gentle on the stomach and is traditionally believed to support digestion, making it a popular everyday beverage in many cultures. With no added sugar or calories, barley tea is a refreshing alternative to sweetened drinks while still providing antioxidants that help combat oxidative stress. Its light, toasty flavor encourages regular hydration, especially for those who find plain water unappealing.
Ingredients
Steps

title: Drinks
text:
Barley grains (pearled or roasted)
Water



Rinse the barley grains thoroughly under running water to remove any dust or impurities.
Heat water in a pot and add the rinsed barley grains.
Bring to a gentle boil, then reduce the heat and simmer for 10–15 minutes, until the water turns light brown and aromatic.
Remove from heat and strain out the barley grains.
Serve hot, or allow the tea to cool and refrigerate for a refreshing cold drink.

title: Appetizers
text:
Pink Grapefruit And Avocado Slices In Dijon Mustard Vinaigrette
Cut the grapefruit and avocado into slices and place them in pairs. Dress them with a layer of Dijon mustard vinaigrette.
Ingredients for the vinaigrette
Steps to make the vinaigrette
Combine the mustard, vinegar, lemon juice, salt, and pepper in a small bowl or measuring cup. Whisk in the oil. Peel the garlic clove and lightly crush, or cut down to the root end with a paring knife, keeping the garlic clove intact. Place in the dressing and allow to marinate for at least 30 minutes. Remove from the dressing before serving.

title: Appetizers
text:
1 rounded tablespoon Dijon mustard
1 ½ tablespoons red wine vinegar or sherry vinegar
1 tablespoon fresh lemon juice
Salt to taste
Freshly ground pepper
½ cup extra virgin olive oil, or use half olive oil and half canola or grapeseed oil
1 small garlic clove

Ingredients
Steps

title: Snacks
text:
Bread slices
Tomato ketchup or pizza sauce
Shredded mozzarella cheese
Pepperoni or other toppings of your choice



Preheat the oven to 400°F (205°C).
Spread an even layer of tomato ketchup or pizza sauce on one side of each bread slice.
Sprinkle shredded mozzarella cheese evenly over the sauce.
Add pepperoni or your preferred toppings on top of the cheese.
Bake for 7–10 minutes, watching closely and removing once the cheese has melted, before the bread turns too crisp.

French Toast
Ingredients
Steps

title: Breakfasts
text:
Two slices of bread
One egg
A couple of tablespoons of milk
Sugar to taste
A drop of vanilla extract
Powdered sugar for dressing (optional)



Whisk the egg with milk and sugar until the sugar is dissolved.
Add a drop of vanilla extract and mix it well.
Pour the mix into a vast and shallow bowl or plate.
Soak the bread slice on both sides.
Shallow fry the soaked bread in butter or oil.

title: Breakfasts
text:
Vegetable Namkeen (salted) Jave (Vermicelli Upma)
Ingredients

Roasted vermicelli (1 cup)
Water (2 cups; twice as much as vermicelli)
Finely chopped onions and tomato
Finely chopped vegetables (carrots and/or peas and/or corn)
Cashews
Oil, cumin seeds, curry leaves, salt, and green chillies

Steps

Heat oil in a deep pan
Add cumin seeds, curry leaves, and green chillies
Caramelize some onions
Add vegetables and sauté them at medium heat
Add tomatoes and cashews
Once the vegetables are cooked and tender, add vermicelli with twice as much water as vermicelli.
Cover and simmer for 10 minutes or until vermicelli is cooked.

title: Roasts
text:
Oven Roasted Tandoori Chicken
Marinate chicken in Shan tandoori chicken masala, food color, curd/lemon juice, and ginger-garlic paste for at least 2 hrs.
Baking Steps

title: Roasts
text:
Preheat oven to 360 degrees.
Place marinated chicken on the baking rack so that the liquids can drip and get collected in the tray.
Cover with foil and cook for 45 minutes.
Uncover, baste with fluids, spray oil, or dribble oil on all the pieces, and bake uncovered for 15 minutes.

Grill mates roasted garlic & herb seasoning https://www.mccormick.com/grill-mates/flavors/seasoning-blends/grill-mates-roasted-garlic-herb-seasoning) or another seasoning of your choice.

Marinate fish fillets on both sides with a mix of seasoning, salt, and pepper, and baste with butter.

Baking Steps

Preheat the oven to 375 degrees.
Bake at 375 degrees for 12 minutes, then broil at low to medium (~ 350 degrees) for 12 - 15 minutes.

title: When To Use What
text:
Wine

Red
Different types of red wine each have unique characteristics that make them suitable for pairing with various foods. Red wines can be categorized based on their sweetness levels, from dry to sweet.
Here’s a brief overview:

Cabernet Sauvignon: A full-bodied red wine, it pairs well with hearty dishes like steak, lamb, and heavy stews.

Sweetness: Typically very dry.

Merlot: Softer than Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot goes well with lighter meats like chicken and other poultry.

Sweetness: Usually dry, with a slight perception of sweetness due to its fruity flavors.

Pinot Noir: A lighter-bodied red, it’s excellent with dishes like salmon, mushroom-based dishes, and grilled meats.

Sweetness: Generally dry

Syrah/Shiraz: Known for its bold flavor, it pairs nicely with spicy dishes, barbecued meats, and game.

Sweetness: Mostly dry, but some styles (especially those from warmer regions) can have a hint of sweetness.

Zinfandel: A medium to full-bodied wine that works well with spicy cuisine, pizza, and hearty pasta dishes.

Sweetness: Ranges from dry to off-dry (slightly sweet), especially in the case of some American Zinfandels.

Malbec: With its robust flavor, it’s great with red meats, particularly beef, and spicy dishes.

Sweetness: Predominantly dry

Sangiovese: This Italian wine is ideal with Italian cuisine, particularly tomato-based pasta dishes and pizza.

Sweetness: Usually dry

Tempranillo: Common in Spanish wines, it pairs well with tapas, grilled meats, and Mexican dishes.

Sweetness: Typically dry

Barbera: Another Italian variety, it’s versatile and pairs well with a range of foods including light meats, pasta, and savory cheese dishes.

Sweetness: Predominantly dry


Remember, the perception of sweetness in wine is not just about sugar content; factors like fruitiness, alcohol level, and acidity can influence how sweet a wine tastes. For instance, a wine with high fruit flavors might seem sweeter, even if it doesn’t have residual sugar.


White
Different white wine types each have unique characteristics and pair well with various foods.
Here are some common types:

Chardonnay: A versatile wine that can range from rich and buttery to fresh and fruity. It pairs well with fish like salmon, chicken, and dishes with a creamy sauce.

Sweetness: Usually dry, though some styles can have a slight sweetness.

Sauvignon Blanc: Known for its crisp, dry, and refreshing taste with hints of green herbs. It goes well with goat cheese, green vegetables like asparagus and zucchini, and dishes with fresh herbs.

Sweetness: Typically very dry with sharp acidity.

Pinot Grigio/Gris: A light, crisp wine often with citrus or pear notes. It’s great with seafood, light pastas, and cheese-cracker combinations.

Sweetness: Generally dry with a crisp finish.

Riesling: Can be sweet or dry, with a fruity and floral aroma. Pairs beautifully with spicy dishes, pork, and sweet desserts.

Sweetness: Can vary greatly but often falls into the off-dry category. Some Rieslings are very sweet, while others are quite dry.

Moscato: Typically sweet with hints of peaches and nectarines. It’s excellent with lighter desserts, fruit-based dishes, and sometimes spicy Asian cuisine.

Sweetness: Known for its sweet profile with flavors of peach and nectarine.

Gewürztraminer: Aromatic and sweet, with notes of tropical fruits. It complements spicy and flavorful Asian dishes, smoked meats, and richer cheeses.

Sweetness: Often off-dry, with a noticeable sweetness balanced by acidity.



Summary

Dry Wines: Sauvignon Blanc, Chardonnay, Pinot Grigio/Gris
Off-Dry (Slightly Sweet) Wines: Riesling, Gewürztraminer
Sweet Wines: Moscato
